importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Andrew allegedly emailed Epstein on this date, stating they were 'in this together,' which revealed ongoing contact and fueled scrutiny over his ties to Epstein and Giuffre.
Andrew gave up all public duties and charity roles in November 2019, marking a turning point in the monarchy's distancing from him due to scandalous media reports.
Andrew reached an out-of-court settlement with Giuffre in 2022, acknowledging her suffering as a victim of sex trafficking without admitting guilt.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2011 to 2025 encompasses the core allegations and ongoing public scrutiny, including the 2011 request to dig up dirt on Giuffre, the 2019 title relinquishment, and the 2025 media coverage and royal accountability discussion.

keyTakeAways: Prince Andrew is under investigation by London police for allegedly asking a bodyguard to investigate Virginia Giuffre’s criminal record in 2011.
The investigation stems from media reports that Andrew provided his bodyguard with Giuffre’s date of birth and social security number to find out if she had a criminal record.
Giuffre, who died by suicide in April 2025 at age 41, was a sexual assault accuser who claims to have been trafficked by Jeffrey Epstein in 2001.
Andrew previously denied allegations of inappropriate contact with Giuffre and denied any wrongdoing, though he acknowledged her suffering in a 2022 out-of-court settlement.
The controversy intensified after emails revealed Andrew maintained contact with Epstein as late as February 2011, contradicting his earlier claims.
British Energy Secretary Ed Miliband criticized the idea of using a police officer for a smear campaign, calling the allegations deeply concerning and inappropriate.
Giuffre’s family welcomed Andrew’s title relinquishment but urged King Charles III to strip him of his title, indicating ongoing public and familial concern.
The scandal has persisted due to the publication of Giuffre’s posthumous memoir, which adds further detail to the allegations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: London police are investigating whether Prince Andrew, in 2011, asked a bodyguard to investigate Virginia Giuffre’s criminal record using her date of birth and social security number, raising serious ethical and legal concerns. The investigation follows media reports and allegations that Andrew had maintained contact with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, including an email in February 2011 stating they were 'in this together.' Giuffre, who died by suicide in April 2025, was a sexual assault accuser who claims to have been trafficked by Epstein. Andrew denied wrongdoing and acknowledged her suffering in a 2022 out-of-court settlement. The controversy intensified after a 2019 public backlash over his ties to Epstein, leading to his relinquishment of public duties and royal titles. Public figures like Ed Miliband have criticized the use of police officers in smear campaigns, and Giuffre’s family has urged King Charles III to strip Andrew of his title, reflecting deep public concern about the monarchy’s accountability.
title: Police Looking into Whether Prince Andrew Enlisted Officer to Dig Up Dirt on Accuser Giuffre
